newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals drift after U.S. data.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals drift after U.S. data.

text.p: Precious metals drifted lower on Thursday afternoon after early New York prices turned slightly easier.
Dealers said U.S. economic data were well in line with economists' forecasts so the reaction in the financial markets was muted limiting the knock on effect in gold.
Business continued light and gold fixed just $1.15 per ounce lower at $326.15 and just five cents above the Wednesday afternoon fixing.
The Decemeber contract on New York's Comex future market was off $0.90 at $329.80.
The dollar and stocks and bonds were slightly firmer after the U.S. July CPI rose 0.2 pct as expected.

Last Friday the U.S. financial markets corrected sharply sending gold to the top of its recent $325-$330 range. Any hope of breaking higher from there depended largely on more moves in the paper markets, dealers said.
"The funds are the shorts in this market and as we're at the top end of the range they're eyeing financials nervously," a dealer said.
"If there's another shake-up on Wall Street we'll see a short-covering move to the upside. Chances are we'll see gold higher," the dealer added.
Indicating the increasing depth of short positions, implied lease rates rose to 2.68 percent for a month from 2.29 percent on Wedndesday and 1.85 percent at the beginning of the week.
Failure to breach resistance could mean prices falling back to $322-$323 support, dealers said.
Silver was steady after moving up with gold on Wednesday and holding most of its gains. It had rallied up to a high bid of $4.56 at one point on Wednesday.
It was off a cent from Wednesay's close at $4.49/$4.51.
Dealers said the market wanted to fill a gap on the September Comex chart which translated to $5.56-$5.60 in the spot market.
"Until it fills that gap, we're not going to see silver too much weaker," a dealer said.
The platinum group metals were easier and dealers said they expected them to continue drifting as Russian exports trickled on to the market.
"They'll continue consolidating and edging lower but the market is still very tight and there's no way I'd be short in these markets," a dealer said.
Platinum was last at $424.00/$427.00, down $8.00 from Wednesday's close, while palladium was off $11.00 at $213.00/$216.00.
